vegetables.description: Non-starchy vegetables are low in calories and carbohydrates, making them ideal for diabetic patients. They are rich in fiber, vitamins, and minerals, which help regulate blood sugar levels.

foods.name: Carrots
foods.benefits: Rich in beta-carotene, which supports eye health and helps regulate blood sugar.
foods.sideEffects: High consumption may temporarily tint the skin orange.

foods.name: Cauliflower
foods.benefits: Low in carbohydrates and high in fiber. Supports digestion and weight management.
foods.sideEffects: May cause bloating or gas in some individuals.

foods.name: Bell Peppers
foods.benefits: Rich in vitamin C and antioxidants. Helps boost immunity.
foods.sideEffects: Generally safe, but may cause mild allergies in some individuals.

foods.name: Zucchini
foods.benefits: Low in calories and high in water content. Supports hydration and digestion.
foods.sideEffects: None known in moderation.

foods.name: Asparagus
foods.benefits: Rich in folate and antioxidants. Helps reduce inflammation.
foods.sideEffects: Can cause a strong odor in urine due to asparagusic acid.

foods.name: Brussels Sprouts
foods.benefits: High in fiber and vitamin K. Supports gut health and bone strength.
foods.sideEffects: May cause bloating or gas in sensitive individuals.

foods.name: Cabbage
foods.benefits: Supports digestion and gut health. Rich in vitamin C.
foods.sideEffects: Excessive consumption may cause bloating.

foods.name: Eggplant
foods.benefits: Rich in fiber and antioxidants. Helps lower blood sugar.
foods.sideEffects: Contains solanine, which may cause mild digestive issues in sensitive individuals.

foods.name: Kale
foods.benefits: Loaded with vitamins and minerals. Helps reduce inflammation and supports heart health.
foods.sideEffects: Excessive consumption may interfere with thyroid function.

foods.name: Tomatoes
foods.benefits: Rich in lycopene, which supports heart health and reduces oxidative stress.
foods.sideEffects: May cause acid reflux in some individuals.

fruits.description: Fruits provide essential vitamins, minerals, and fiber. While they contain natural sugars, many have a low glycemic index and can be consumed in moderation.

foods.name: Berries
foods.benefits: High in antioxidants and fiber. Helps regulate blood sugar and supports heart health.
foods.sideEffects: None known in moderation.

foods.name: Apples
foods.benefits: Rich in fiber and antioxidants. Helps improve digestion and supports heart health.
foods.sideEffects: Excessive consumption may cause digestive issues due to high fiber.

foods.name: Pears
foods.benefits: Rich in fiber and vitamin C. Supports digestive health and boosts immunity.
foods.sideEffects: Excessive intake may cause bloating or stomach discomfort.

foods.name: Oranges
foods.benefits: High in vitamin C. Helps boost immunity and maintain hydration.
foods.sideEffects: May cause acid reflux in sensitive individuals.

foods.name: Cherries
foods.benefits: Rich in antioxidants and anti-inflammatory properties. Supports joint and heart health.
foods.sideEffects: Overconsumption may lead to digestive discomfort due to sorbitol content.

foods.name: Peaches
foods.benefits: Rich in vitamins A and C. Supports skin health and digestion.
foods.sideEffects: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.

foods.name: Plums
foods.benefits: Good source of fiber and antioxidants. Helps regulate digestion.
foods.sideEffects: May cause mild laxative effects if consumed in excess.

foods.name: Kiwi
foods.benefits: High in vitamin C and fiber. Supports digestion and immunity.
foods.sideEffects: May cause allergic reactions in some people.

foods.name: Grapefruit
foods.benefits: Low in calories and rich in vitamin C. Aids in weight management and heart health.
foods.sideEffects: Can interfere with certain medications.

foods.name: Pomegranate
foods.benefits: Packed with antioxidants and vitamins. Supports heart health and reduces inflammation.
foods.sideEffects: May cause stomach upset if consumed in large quantities.

proteins.description: Proteins are essential for muscle repair and growth. Choose lean and plant-based proteins for better health.

foods.name: Chicken Breast
foods.benefits: High in protein and low in fat. Supports muscle growth and weight management.
foods.sideEffects: None known in moderation.

foods.name: Tofu
foods.benefits: Plant-based protein. Helps lower cholesterol and supports heart health.
foods.sideEffects: May cause bloating in some individuals.

foods.name: Salmon
foods.benefits: Rich in omega-3 fatty acids. Supports brain and heart health.
foods.sideEffects: May contain mercury; limit intake for safety.

foods.name: Lentils
foods.benefits: High in fiber and protein. Helps regulate blood sugar and digestion.
foods.sideEffects: May cause gas or bloating.

foods.name: Eggs
foods.benefits: Rich in high-quality protein and essential vitamins. Supports brain function.
foods.sideEffects: High cholesterol; should be consumed in moderation.

foods.name: Almonds
foods.benefits: Good source of plant protein and healthy fats. Helps in blood sugar control.
foods.sideEffects: May cause allergic reactions in some individuals.

foods.name: Cottage Cheese
foods.benefits: High in protein and calcium. Supports bone health and muscle recovery.
foods.sideEffects: May cause digestive issues in lactose-intolerant individuals.

foods.name: Turkey
foods.benefits: Lean protein with low fat. Helps in muscle repair and immune function.
foods.sideEffects: Processed turkey may contain preservatives.

foods.name: Greek Yogurt
foods.benefits: Rich in probiotics and protein. Supports gut health and digestion.
foods.sideEffects: May contain added sugars in flavored varieties.

foods.name: Quinoa
foods.benefits: Complete plant protein with all essential amino acids. Helps regulate blood sugar.
foods.sideEffects: May cause bloating in some individuals.
